title: College Chapel Session Gone Wrong
description:
I was visiting a college and sat through a gruelingly terrible exegetical presentation of John 15.

This is episode 91 of my podcast.

My Writing: https://coltonkirby.substack.com/

There is an audio version of my videos (on all podcast platforms): https://anchor.fm/coltonkirby

About Me: https://coltonkirby.substack.com/about
Twitter: https://twitter.com/_coltonkirby
Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/officialcoltonkirby
Goodreads: https://www.goodreads.com/user/show/129883782-colton-kirby
Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/officialcoltonkirby/
Pinterest: https://www.pinterest.com/coltonjkirby/_saved/
Odysee: https://odysee.com/@ColtonKirby
Books Wish List: https://docs.google.com/document/d/19GTqvKmd3Ter2WCpBwU2DkuD-Qse6xiLAqJFGZzWToo/edit?usp=sharing

If you want to financially support what I’m doing, you can give one-off donations here (thank you): https://www.paypal.me/ColtonKirby

transcript_parts.text: so I'm out visiting a college and uh
this college I just visited I'm supposed
to be getting my lunch so I'm going to
make this short and quick uh they just
had a chapel and uh the speaker for
Chapel it was really interesting because
um he was going through Isaiah 5 and
then John 15 about the vine and the
branches and I was just thinking during
the speech of the incredible
theological suicide that was being
committed when you know um it says in
John 15 for example
um greater love has no men than this
then he'd lay down his life for his
friends this whole passage is talking
about how if I if you abide in me I will
abide in you it's this reciprocal thing
that we're participating in and it's and
then he was just completely murdering it
with some kind of
quasi-calvinistic interpretation and
when in the next verse from
um greater love has no man than this and
then I lay down his life for his friends
when it says that uh and you are my
friends if you do what I command
just completely basically skipped over
it his comment to that was um he's
talking about how he's gonna die and it
was this whole speech about how um you
know we we don't do anything to be saved
which is true in a sense and then you
know just kind of frustrating and I was
just sitting there listening to it and
partly
probably part of my frustration is uh
yesterday I was listening to uh our in
half hour 45 uh podcasts of David Hart
David Bentley heart
um commenting on his translation of The
Sermon on the Mount and uh just some of
his thoughts and then clashing against
the thoughts of the speaker here at
Chapel and um just interesting this
insistence we have in some of these
Protestant theological circles that
almost like we don't have almost like we
have no obligation of doing anything
good and I know that they wouldn't say
that but it's kind of like let's read
the text and see what it actually says
and not
come to it with our set of
presuppositions and like and I'm not
saying read the text naively or read the
text intuitively exactly but I'm saying
if we were sitting there and obviously
I'm not reading the Greek or anything
I'm I'm reading a translation but like
if I'm taking it verse reverse not these
verses stand alone and I'm doing this
kind of
gross Systematic Theology where I take a
certain verse and then another verse
from two completely different books two
completely different parts of the Canon
and try to harmonize them what if we
read the text as a whole the paragraphs
the sentences the verses the chapters
the book
and then get an understanding of that
before I take this one little phrase
from this book and compare it to this
other book and then superimpose what I
can um synthesize from that onto the
rest of that paragraph that I first got
the first verse from so anyways just a
little bit of thoughts on this and um
so I'm making these short videos I
thought I would make a video so thanks
for watching God bless
